content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted H.R. 5658 for Treasury and General Government Appropriations. Funding was provided for the General Services Administration and Executive Residence for White House transition. P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475) partially funded transportation appropriations. Title V of H.R. 4475, the Transportation appropriations bill, partially funds select accounts from the Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government primary funding measure. Prior to P.L. 106-554, which enacted FY2001 Treasury and General Government appropriations, various measures were considered to fund affected accounts. Key measures include House bill H.R. 4871, Senate bill S. 2900, and the Legislative Branch Appropriation conference report. The Legislative Branch Appropriation conference report or H.R. 4516 / H.R. 4985 was vetoed on October 30. Transportation Appropriations under P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475) provided partial funding and general provisions. FY2001 Continuing Funding Resolution under P.L. 106-275, as amended, and P.L. 106-426 funded the presidential transition. P.L. 106-554 enacted H.R. 5658 for Treasury and General Government funding. The President submits the Budget of the United States Government annually to Congress. Congress passes a concurrent resolution establishing the congressional budget and setting budgetary levels for future years. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees then allocate discretionary funding levels. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees allocate discretionary funding levels to subcommittees. This includes funding for the Department of the Treasury, law enforcement organizations, and the Internal Revenue Service. The Treasury appropriations cover various agencies including the Internal Revenue Service, Financial Management Service, and Bureau of the Public Debt. The U.S. Postal Service is mostly self-supporting, with limited federal contributions for specific purposes like free postal service for the blind. Appropriations for the Executive Office of the President fund salaries, expenses, and operations of various agencies within the EOP. The Treasury appropriations fund various agencies including the Internal Revenue Service, Financial Management Service, and Bureau of the Public Debt. The Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) distributes funding for drug control initiatives to other entities. Independent agencies like the Federal Election Commission and the National Archives are also financed through this appropriation. The general titles in addition to the specific agency funding cover governmentwide restrictions and actions. For example, there are standard language provisions prohibiting the use of funds for non-U.S. citizens, requiring drug-free workplaces, and authorizing travel expenses for federal employees' immediate family members serving overseas. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes a .22% rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds affecting all Treasury and General Government appropriations. The Office of Management and Budget must report on the implementation of the rescission when the FY2002 budget is submitted. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes a .22% rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds affecting all Treasury and General Government appropriations. The Office of Management Budget issued guidelines for agencies to implement the rescission, applying it equally to all programs, projects, and activities subject to the reduction. Advance appropriations for FY 2001 provided in FY 2000 or earlier years are included in the rescission, while advance appropriations for FY 2002 and beyond are exempt. Discretionary emergency appropriations are also subject to the rescission. The .22% rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds affects all Treasury and General Government appropriations. Agencies will receive their rescission amounts by account from their OMB representative. The FY2000 Consolidated Appropriations Act mandated a 0.38% across-the-board rescission, with specific reductions reported by OMB in the FY2001 budget submission. The FY2000 Consolidated Appropriations Act mandated a 0.38% across-the-board rescission, with specific reductions reported by OMB in the FY2001 budget submission. OMB issued a fact sheet stating that each department must achieve 0.38% in savings, with some flexibility to protect high-priority programs. The FY2001 rescission provisions exempt certain programs but are otherwise universally applied. The FY2001 Military Construction Appropriations Act includes the FY2000 Supplemental funding provisions. The FY2000 Supplemental funding provisions impact accounts covered by the Treasury/Postal Service measure. For example, it reverts the pay date for federal civilian personnel to the original scheduled date in FY2000, altering the funding levels. The House Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government held hearings in March and April 2000. The House passed H.R. 4871 on July 20, 2000, by a vote of 216-202. The Senate Committee on Appropriations Subcommittee on Treasury, Postal Service, and General Government held hearings and sent the bill to the full Appropriations Committee. Cloture was invoked on July 26 by a vote of 97-0, and debate on the measure began. On July 26, 2000, Treasury Appropriations Subcommittee Chairman introduced H.R. 4985 for fiscal year ending September 30, 2001. On July 27, 2000, the House agreed to the conference report for H.R. 4516 (FY2001) after waiving points of order. On September 14, 2000, the House approved funding for the Treasury and General Government accounts in the FY2001 legislative branch funding bill. The development of ACE is a complex and high-risk endeavor that supports Customs' ability to collect billions of dollars in revenue generated by imports. Customs generates offsetting receipts from two user fee programs related to conveyance, passengers, and bulk cargo from Mexico and Canada. The second fee program, the commerce-related merchandise processing fee (MPF), was established by the 1986 Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act (OBRA). There are restrictions on the use of COBRA fee receipts, initially used for overtime costs for inspectors and canine enforcement officers. Surplus revenues could be used for other purposes. Selected definitions from the "Glossary of Budgetary Terms" are included in the Manual on the Federal Budget Process. The Manual on the Federal Budget Process defines key terms related to budgeting and accounting, including Account, Appropriation, Authorization, and Budget Authority. These terms are crucial for understanding the federal budget process. Budget authority includes appropriations, borrowing authority, and contract authority. A budget resolution is a concurrent resolution passed by Congress setting forth the budget for at least the next five fiscal years. A continuing resolution provides budget authority to agencies or programs when regular appropriations have not been enacted. Continuing resolutions are temporary measures that provide budget authority to programs when regular appropriations have not been enacted. Direct spending, also known as mandatory spending, is budget authority provided in laws other than annual appropriations acts. It is subject to the PAGO rules and is distinguished from discretionary spending. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, is subject to PAGO rules. Discretionary spending is budget authority provided in annual appropriations acts. Federal funds encompass all government monies except trust funds. Outlays are payments made to fulfill obligations. The PAGO process, established by the Budget Enforcement Act, ensures that revenue and direct spending legislation does not increase the deficit or reduce the surplus. It requires any deficit increase or surplus reduction to be offset by other legislation or sequestration. The reconciliation process allows Congress to change existing laws to align with tax and spending policies. The reconciliation process in the Congressional Budget Act allows Congress to align tax and spending levels with a budget resolution. Scorekeeping tracks congressional budget actions, and supplemental appropriations provide additional budget authority.
